mn121:1.1.comm: This sutta gives a unique approach to meditation on emptiness, using the perception of relative emptiness as a foundation for absorption. | The topic of emptiness does not play the central role in Pali texts that it did in later Buddhism. This is perhaps at least partly due to different doctrinal developments in the early Buddhist schools. Passages that in the Pali mention impermanence, suffering, and not-self, in parallels of the (Mūla)-Sarvāstivāda often include emptiness as well. This does not indicate any doctrinal contradiction, as emptiness is explained as meaning not-self. But it does suggest that the presentation in terms of emptiness was more popular in that group of schools.

mn121:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
mn121:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

mn121:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn121:2.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Ānanda came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

mn121:3.1.pli: “Ekamidaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati nagarakaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamo.
mn121:3.1.eng: “Sir, this one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans where they have a town named Townsville.

mn121:3.2.pli: Tattha me, bhante, bhagavato sammukhā sutaṃ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:
mn121:3.2.eng: There I heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
mn121:3.2.comm: “I heard and learned this in the presence” (sammukhā sutaṁ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ) is the phrase used in the suttas when reporting a teaching heard directly from the Buddha, eg. SN 55.52:5.1, SN 22.90:9.1, MN 47:10.7, etc.

mn121:3.3.eng: ‘Ānanda, these days I usually practice the meditation on emptiness.’
mn121:3.3.comm: The same thing is said by Sāriputta at MN 151:2.3, upon which the Buddha encourages him to reflect on the purity of his almsfood. Before the Second Council, the elder monk Sabbakāmī revealed that emptiness was his main practice too (Kd 22:2.5.9), while at Thig 3.3:2.1, the bhikkhunī Uttamā also claims to practice emptiness meditation. The release through emptiness is classified along with absorption as a superhuman attainment (Bu Pj 4:4.1.6). At MN 43:33.1 = SN 41.7:4.1, the “release of the heart through emptiness” is a reflection on not-self (see too SN 35.85:1.4, AN 9.36:2.4, Snp 5.16:4.1, Thag 19.1:27.2).

mn121:3.4.pli: Kacci metaṃ, bhante, sussutaṃ suggahitaṃ sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritan”ti?
mn121:3.4.eng: I trust I properly heard, learned, applied the mind, and remembered that from the Buddha?”
mn121:3.4.comm: Notice the process of learning teachings through active engagement. Simply “hearing” it is just the beginning.

mn121:3.5.pli: “Taggha te etaṃ, ānanda, sussutaṃ suggahitaṃ sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ.
mn121:3.5.eng: “Indeed, Ānanda, you properly heard, learned, applied the mind, and remembered that.

mn121:3.6.pli: Pubbepāhaṃ, ānanda, etarahipi suññatāvihārena bahulaṃ viharāmi.
mn121:3.6.eng: Now, as before, I usually practice the meditation on emptiness.

mn121:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, ayaṃ migāramātupāsādo suñño hatthigavassavaḷavena, suñño jātarūparajatena, suñño itthipurisasannipātena atthi cevidaṃ asuññataṃ yadidaṃ—
mn121:4.1.eng: Consider this stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother. It’s empty of elephants, cows, horses, and mares; of gold and silver; and of gatherings of men and women.
mn121:4.1.comm: Emptiness is not a metaphysical property, but a relative state: something is empty of something.

mn121:4.2.eng: There is only this that is not emptiness, namely, the oneness dependent on the mendicant Saṅgha.
mn121:4.2.comm: Oneness, like emptiness, is a relative concept. Those things that are more distracting and tempting are absent, leaving only that which is more peaceful.

mn121:4.3.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, bhikkhu amanasikaritvā gāmasaññaṃ, amanasikaritvā manussasaññaṃ, araññasaññaṃ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṃ.
mn121:4.3.eng: In the same way, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the village and the perception of people—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of wilderness.

mn121:4.4.pli: Tassa araññasaññāya cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
mn121:4.4.eng: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that perception of wilderness.

mn121:4.6.pli: ‘ye assu darathā gāmasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā manussasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṃ darathamattā yadidaṃ—
mn121:4.6.eng: ‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of village or the perception of people.

mn121:4.7.eng: There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of wilderness.’

mn121:4.8.pli: So ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ gāmasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ manussasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṃ asuññataṃ yadidaṃ—
mn121:4.8.eng: They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of the village. It is empty of the perception of people.

mn121:4.9.eng: There is only this that is not emptiness, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of wilderness.’

mn121:4.10.pli: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṃ suññaṃ samanupassati, yaṃ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti taṃ ‘santamidaṃ atthī’ti pajānāti.
mn121:4.10.eng: And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present.
mn121:4.10.comm: That is to say, the “purity” of the emptiness is not because everything is empty, but because what is empty is accurately recognized as empty.

mn121:4.11.pli: Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.
mn121:4.11.eng: That’s how emptiness manifests in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

mn121:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhu amanasikaritvā manussasaññaṃ, amanasikaritvā araññasaññaṃ, pathavīsaññaṃ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṃ.
mn121:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of people and the perception of wilderness—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of earth.

mn121:5.2.pli: Tassa pathavīsaññāya cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
mn121:5.2.eng: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that perception of earth.

mn121:5.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, āsabhacammaṃ saṅkusatena suvihataṃ vigatavalikaṃ;
mn121:5.3.eng: As a bull’s hide is rid of folds when fully stretched out by a hundred pegs,

mn121:5.4.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, bhikkhu yaṃ imissā pathaviyā ukkūlavikkūlaṃ nadīviduggaṃ khāṇukaṇṭakaṭṭhānaṃ pabbatavisamaṃ taṃ sabbaṃ amanasikaritvā pathavīsaññaṃ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṃ.
mn121:5.4.eng: so too, ignoring the hilly terrain, inaccessible riverlands, stumps and thorns, and rugged mountains, they focus on the oneness dependent on the perception of earth.
mn121:5.4.comm: The perception of earth is an idealized inner conceptual image. This is the “form” (rūpa) that is the basis for “absorption on luminous form” (rūpajjhāna). The commentaries call this the nimitta (“sign”).

mn121:5.5.pli: Tassa pathavīsaññāya cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
mn121:5.5.eng: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that perception of earth.

mn121:5.7.pli: ‘ye assu darathā manussasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā araññasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṃ darathamattā yadidaṃ—
mn121:5.7.eng: ‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of people or the perception of wilderness.

mn121:5.8.eng: There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of earth.’

mn121:5.9.pli: So ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ manussasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ araññasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṃ asuññataṃ yadidaṃ—
mn121:5.9.eng: They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of people. It is empty of the perception of wilderness.

mn121:5.10.eng: There is only this that is not emptiness, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of earth.’

mn121:5.11.pli: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṃ suññaṃ samanupassati, yaṃ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti taṃ ‘santamidaṃ atthī’ti pajānāti.
mn121:5.11.eng: And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present.

mn121:5.12.pli: Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.
mn121:5.12.eng: That’s how emptiness manifests in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

mn121:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhu amanasikaritvā araññasaññaṃ, amanasikaritvā pathavīsaññaṃ, ākāsānañcāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṃ.
mn121:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of wilderness and the perception of earth—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite space.
mn121:6.1.comm: The meditator moves from a practice dependent on an aspect of “form” (rūpa), namely the idealized image of earth as the basis for the four absorptions, to the formless meditations.

mn121:6.2.pli: Tassa ākāsānañcāyatanasaññāya cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
mn121:6.2.eng: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that perception of the dimension of infinite space.

mn121:6.4.pli: ‘ye assu darathā araññasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā pathavīsaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṃ darathamattā yadidaṃ—
mn121:6.4.eng: ‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of wilderness or the perception of earth.

mn121:6.5.eng: There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite space.’

mn121:6.6.pli: So ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ araññasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ pathavīsaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṃ asuññataṃ yadidaṃ—
mn121:6.6.eng: They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of wilderness. It is empty of the perception of earth.

mn121:6.7.eng: There is only this that is not emptiness, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite space.’

mn121:6.8.pli: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṃ suññaṃ samanupassati, yaṃ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti taṃ ‘santamidaṃ atthī’ti pajānāti.
mn121:6.8.eng: And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present.

mn121:6.9.pli: Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.
mn121:6.9.eng: That’s how emptiness manifests in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

mn121:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhu amanasikaritvā pathavīsaññaṃ, amanasikaritvā ākāsānañcāyatanasaññaṃ, viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṃ.
mn121:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of earth and the perception of the dimension of infinite space—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness.

mn121:7.2.pli: Tassa viññāṇañcāyatanasaññāya cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
mn121:7.2.eng: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness.

mn121:7.4.pli: ‘ye assu darathā pathavīsaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā ākāsānañcāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṃ darathamattā yadidaṃ—
mn121:7.4.eng: ‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of earth or the perception of the dimension of infinite space.

mn121:7.5.eng: There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness.’

mn121:7.6.pli: So ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ pathavīsaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ ākāsānañcāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṃ asuññataṃ yadidaṃ—
mn121:7.6.eng: They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of earth. It is empty of the perception of the dimension of infinite space.

mn121:7.7.eng: There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness.’

mn121:7.8.pli: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṃ suññaṃ samanupassati, yaṃ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti taṃ ‘santamidaṃ atthī’ti pajānāti.
mn121:7.8.eng: And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present.

mn121:7.9.pli: Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.
mn121:7.9.eng: That’s how emptiness manifests in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

mn121:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhu amanasikaritvā ākāsānañcāyatanasaññaṃ, amanasikaritvā viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṃ, ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṃ.
mn121:8.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the dimension of infinite space and the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of nothingness.

mn121:8.2.pli: Tassa ākiñcaññāyatanasaññāya cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
mn121:8.2.eng: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that perception of the dimension of nothingness.

mn121:8.4.pli: ‘ye assu darathā ākāsānañcāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṃ darathamattā yadidaṃ—
mn121:8.4.eng: ‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of the dimension of infinite space or the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness.

mn121:8.5.eng: There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of nothingness.’

mn121:8.6.pli: So ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ ākāsānañcāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ viññāṇañcāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṃ asuññataṃ yadidaṃ—
mn121:8.6.eng: They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of the dimension of infinite space. It is empty of the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness.

mn121:8.7.eng: There is only this that is not emptiness, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of nothingness.’

mn121:8.8.pli: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṃ suññaṃ samanupassati, yaṃ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti taṃ ‘santamidaṃ atthī’ti pajānāti.
mn121:8.8.eng: And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present.

mn121:8.9.pli: Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.
mn121:8.9.eng: That’s how emptiness manifests in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

mn121:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda bhikkhu amanasikaritvā viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṃ, amanasikaritvā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṃ.
mn121:9.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness and the perception of the dimension of nothingness—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn121:9.2.pli: Tassa nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññāya cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
mn121:9.2.eng: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn121:9.4.pli: ‘ye assu darathā viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṃ darathamattā yadidaṃ—
mn121:9.4.eng: ‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness or the perception of the dimension of nothingness.

mn121:9.5.eng: There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

mn121:9.6.pli: So ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ viññāṇañcāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ ākiñcaññāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṃ asuññataṃ yadidaṃ—
mn121:9.6.eng: They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness. It is empty of the perception of the dimension of nothingness.

mn121:9.7.eng: There is only this that is not emptiness, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

mn121:9.8.pli: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṃ suññaṃ samanupassati, yaṃ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti taṃ ‘santamidaṃ atthī’ti pajānāti.
mn121:9.8.eng: And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present.

mn121:9.9.pli: Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.
mn121:9.9.eng: That’s how emptiness manifests in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

mn121:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhu amanasikaritvā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ, amanasikaritvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṃ, animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṃ.
mn121:10.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the dimension of nothingness and the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception—focuses on the oneness dependent on the signless immersion of the heart.
mn121:10.1.comm: The defining characteristic of the “signless immersion of the heart” is that consciousness does not “follow after signs” (nimittānusāri viññāṇaṁ, eg. AN 6.13:5.3). This is explained in MN 138:10.2 as not being distracted or affected by the features of sense impressions, as the “signs” are created by greed, hate, and delusion (MN 43:37.1). By itself, however, it does not necessarily indicate that one is awakened (AN 6.60:8.2), as good conduct is still required for progress (AN 7.56:13.1). It was practiced by Moggallāna before awakening, who had to be urged to “not follow any signs” (SN 40.9). It may also be used to describe the meditation of an arahant (SN 41.7:6.12).

mn121:10.2.pli: Tassa animitte cetosamādhimhi cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
mn121:10.2.eng: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that signless immersion of the heart.

mn121:10.4.pli: ‘ye assu darathā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṃ darathamattā yadidaṃ—
mn121:10.4.eng: ‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of the dimension of nothingness or the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn121:10.5.eng: There is only this modicum of stress, namely that related to the six sense fields dependent on this body and conditioned by life.’
mn121:10.5.comm: Unlike with deep absorption, where there is no experience of the physical body, the signless meditation is a state of advanced discernment or insight where the six senses are seen as they truly are. This explains why it was a way for the Buddha to ease the pains of old age (DN 16:2.25.13). It seems that in such a state, the Buddha was able to function normally while seeing through the pain in his body.

mn121:10.6.pli: So ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ ākiñcaññāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññāyā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṃ asuññataṃ yadidaṃ—
mn121:10.6.eng: They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of the dimension of nothingness. It is empty of the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn121:10.7.eng: There is only this that is not emptiness, namely that related to the six sense fields dependent on this body and conditioned by life.’

mn121:10.8.pli: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṃ suññaṃ samanupassati, yaṃ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti taṃ ‘santamidaṃ atthī’ti pajānāti.
mn121:10.8.eng: And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present.

mn121:10.9.pli: Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.
mn121:10.9.eng: That’s how emptiness manifests in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.

mn121:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhu amanasikaritvā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ, amanasikaritvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṃ, animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ paṭicca manasi karoti ekattaṃ.
mn121:11.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the dimension of nothingness and the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception—focuses on the oneness dependent on the signless immersion of the heart.

mn121:11.2.pli: Tassa animitte cetosamādhimhi cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
mn121:11.2.eng: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that signless immersion of the heart.

mn121:11.4.eng: ‘Even this signless immersion of the heart is produced by choices and intentions.’
mn121:11.4.comm: Liberating insight comes from insight into the state of signless meditation, that is to say, it is the insight into insight itself.

mn121:11.5.pli: ‘Yaṃ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcetayitaṃ tadaniccaṃ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
mn121:11.5.eng: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’

mn121:11.6.pli: Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati.
mn121:11.6.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

mn121:11.7.eng: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

mn121:11.8.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
mn121:11.8.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

mn121:12.2.pli: ‘ye assu darathā kāmāsavaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā bhavāsavaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, ye assu darathā avijjāsavaṃ paṭicca tedha na santi, atthi cevāyaṃ darathamattā yadidaṃ—
mn121:12.2.eng: ‘Here there is no stress due to the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, or ignorance.

mn121:12.3.eng: There is only this modicum of stress, namely that related to the six sense fields dependent on this body and conditioned by life.’

mn121:12.4.pli: So ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ kāmāsavenā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ bhavāsavenā’ti pajānāti, ‘suññamidaṃ saññāgataṃ avijjāsavenā’ti pajānāti, ‘atthi cevidaṃ asuññataṃ yadidaṃ—
mn121:12.4.eng: They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
mn121:12.4.comm: The “field of perception” (saññāgataṁ) is the scope of awareness.

mn121:12.5.eng: There is only this that is not emptiness, namely that related to the six sense fields dependent on this body and conditioned by life.’

mn121:12.6.pli: Iti yañhi kho tattha na hoti tena taṃ suññaṃ samanupassati, yaṃ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti taṃ ‘santamidaṃ atthī’ti pajānāti.
mn121:12.6.eng: And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present.

mn121:12.7.pli: Evampissa esā, ānanda, yathābhuccā avipallatthā parisuddhā paramānuttarā suññatāvakkanti bhavati.
mn121:12.7.eng: That’s how emptiness manifests in them—genuine, undistorted, pure, and supreme.

mn121:13.1.pli: Yepi hi keci, ānanda, atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā parisuddhaṃ paramānuttaraṃ suññataṃ upasampajja vihariṃsu, sabbe te imaṃyeva parisuddhaṃ paramānuttaraṃ suññataṃ upasampajja vihariṃsu.
mn121:13.1.eng: Whatever ascetics and brahmins enter and remain in the pure, ultimate, supreme emptiness—whether in the past, future, or present—all of them enter and remain in this same pure, ultimate, supreme emptiness.
mn121:13.1.comm: Here the emptiness is distinguished as “supreme” (anuttara). In early Pali, Nibbāna is not described as either empty or as not-self, as these are properties of the path. This passage is probably the closest we get to that, but even this is relative, since the body and life persist.

mn121:13.2.pli: Yepi hi keci, ānanda, anāgatamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā parisuddhaṃ paramānuttaraṃ suññataṃ upasampajja viharissanti, sabbe te imaṃyeva parisuddhaṃ paramānuttaraṃ suññataṃ upasampajja viharissanti.

mn121:13.3.pli: Yepi hi keci, ānanda, etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā parisuddhaṃ paramānuttaraṃ suññataṃ upasampajja viharanti, sabbe te imaṃyeva parisuddhaṃ paramānuttaraṃ suññataṃ upasampajja viharanti.

mn121:13.4.pli: Tasmātiha, ānanda, ‘parisuddhaṃ paramānuttaraṃ suññataṃ upasampajja viharissāmā’ti—
mn121:13.4.eng: So, Ānanda, you should train like this: ‘We will enter and remain in the pure, ultimate, supreme emptiness.’

mn121:13.6.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn121:13.7.pli: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn121:13.7.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
